name: Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site
description: In the 1600's, on the banks of the Saugus River, something extraordinary happened! Explore the place where European iron makers brought their special skills to a young Massachusetts colony. Saugus Iron Works is a twelve-acre National Historic Site that includes working waterwheels, forges, mills, a historic 17th century home, and a lush river basin.
shortDescription: In the 1600's, on the banks of the Saugus River, something extraordinary happened! Explore the place where European iron makers brought their special skills to a young Massachusetts colony. Saugus Iro...

operatingHours.description: All outdoor spaces including the grounds and walking paths are accessible 7 days a week. Please check the visitor center hours to learn more about which facilities are open.

climate.weatherDescription: New England weather is unpredictable year-round. Monthly averages, in degrees Fahrenheit, are: January: 37 high, 20 low February: 40 high, 23 low March: 47 high, 30 low April: 57 high, 38 low May: 67 high, 48 low June: 76 high, 58 low July: 82 high, 63 low August: 80 high, 62 low September: 73 high, 55 low October: 62 high, 45 low November: 52 high, 37 low December: 42 high, 27 low

images.title: Saugus Iron Works Landscape
images.altText: Several wooden structures amid green fields and trees under partly cloudy sky and beside river.
images.caption: A view of Saugus Iron Works from the Saugus River

images.title: Iron Forge
images.altText: Approximately 15' by 15' spoked wooden wheel beside river and under blue sky.
images.caption: The forge is where bars of pig iron created at the blast furnace were changed into a new kind of iron that a blacksmith was able to use.

images.title: Blast Furnace
images.altText: Rectangular wooden structure between orange deciduous trees and wooden bridge with walkway.
images.caption: The blast furnace is where bog ore was smelted to create cast iron "pig" bars.
